questions.text: What is the age at which the gender of the fetus can be determined?
questions.solution:
The gender of the fetus can be determined at 16 weeks of gestation. The length of the fetus is 16 cm and weight 120 g.

Other features that can be seen at 16 weeks include -

  • Lanugo hair is visible on the body.
  • Pupillary membrane is visible.
  • Meconium is seen in the upper part of the small intestine.
  • Fingerprints are formed.
  • Buds for all 20 temporary teeth are laid down.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:351.

choices.text: It is white, creamy, naturally occurring biofilm covering the skin of the fetus during the last trimester of pregnancy.
It contains water-containing corneocytes embedded in a lipid matrix.
Absence of vernix caseosa is useful sign to determine live birth
Hospital needs to preserve vernix caseosa for DNA analysis

questions.text: Which of the following statement/s is/are false regarding vernix caseosa?
questions.solution:
• Vernix caseosa is white, creamy, naturally occurring biofilm covering the skin of the fetus during the last trimester of pregnancy.
  • It contains water-containingcorneocytes embedded in a lipid matrix.
  • Absence of vernix caseosa indicates that the child had been washed, suggesting that it survived for sometime after birth.
  • Hospital need not preserve vernix caseosa for DNA analysis. Instead, blood can is useful.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:349.

questions.text: Quaternary blast injuries are
questions.solution: Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:316-17.

questions.text: Butterfly pattern in chest X-ray is seen in which of the following cases?
questions.solution:
In primary blast injury, chest radiographs show-

  • Initial stages - Show localised contusion
  • Later stages - As the time passes, the effect becomes generalized with bilateral fluffy infiltrates spreading out from the hilum of both lungs-'butterfly' pattern.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:316-17.

questions.text: Marshall's triad in blast injury includes all except
questions.solution:
Marshall's triad in blast injury includes -

  • Bruises
  • Abrasions
  • Punctate lacerations with tattooing of the body

This indicates bomb explosion.

External injuries in blast cases can include:

  • Total body disintegration indicates high-order condensed explosive at close range.
  • There may be mangling of body near explosion with parts of extremities amputated; craniofacial injuries are seen in case of suicide.
  • Lower limb amputation is typical of standing or seated individual.
  • Hand injuries are seen, if an explosive device was held.
  • There may be projectile injury.
  • Punctate lacerations, dust tattooing and black soiling from explosive materials may be seen.
  • Injuries may be seen due to fallen rubble.
  • Burns (flash burns and singed hair seen on victims in immediate vicinity) can be seen.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:318.

questions.text: Which is the most common organ affected by primary blast injury?
questions.solution:
• Primary blast injuries are characterised by the absence of external injuries.
  • They are usually internal injuries which are often unrecognised and their severity underestimated.
  • The ears are most often affected by the overpressure, followed by the lungs and the hollow organs of the GIT.
  • GIT injuries may present after a delay of hours or even days.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:316.

questions.text: Female castration comes under which clause of Sec 320, IPC?
questions.solution:
Female castration can be a grievous hurt under clause 4 or 8 of Sec. 320 IPC.

Sec. 320 IPC defines the grievous hurt and comprises of eight clauses. The clauses of Sec 320, IPC are:

  • First : Emasculation (Includes male castration).
  • Second : Permanent privation of the sight of either eye.
  • Third: Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.
  • Fourth : Privation of any member (includes eyes, ears, nostrils, mouth, hands or feet) or joint.
  • Fifth: Destruction or permanent impairing of the powers of any member or joint.
  • Sixth : Permanent disfiguration of the head or face.
  • Seventh : Fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth.
  • Eighth: Any hurt which
  • Endangers life.
  • Or which causes the sufferer to be during the space of 20 days in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:323-26.

questions.text: Incised wound on abdomen exposing gut comes under which clause of Sec 320, IPC?
questions.solution:
Sec. 320 IPC defines the grievous hurt and comprises of eight clauses. The clauses of Sec 320, IPC are:

  • First : Emasculation (Includes male castration).
  • Second : Permanent privation of the sight of either eye.
  • Third: Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.
  • Fourth: Privation of any member (includes eyes, ears, nostrils, mouth, hands or feet) or joint.
  • Fifth: Destruction or permanent impairing of the powers of any member or joint.
  • Sixth : Permanent disfiguration of the head or face.
  • Seventh: Fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth.
  • Eighth: Any hurt which
  • Endangers life.
  • Or which causes the sufferer to be during the space of 20 days in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:323-26.

questions.text: How much blood can be lost in a closed fracture of femur bone?
questions.solution:
Approximate blood loss in fracture of long bone are as below:

  • Humerus: 200-500 ml
  • Tibia with/without fibula: 500-700 ml
  • Femur: 1000-1500 ml
  • Pelvis: > 2000 ml

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:328.

questions.text: Ewing's postulate helps to relate causal relationship between
questions.solution:
In some cases, there is apparent relationship between tumour and some preceding trauma to the part. E.g., Development of osteogenic sarcoma and osteoclastoma after injury, malignancy in burn scars or on the skin adjacent to a chronic osteomyelitis sinus.

Since trauma disrupts tissue, it might activate a pre-existing tumour to grow and spread more rapidly.

In accepting a relationship between trauma and malignancy, following Ewing's postulates should be satisfied:

  1. The tumour site prior to injury was normal.
  2. Undeniable and adequate trauma to disrupt the continuity must be proved.
  3. The tumour followed the injury within a reasonable time interval (between a minimum of 3-4 weeks and maximum of 3 years after receipt of injury).
  4. The tumour must have originated in the part of the body that has sustained the injury.
  5. The tumour must be of histological type that could originate from the cells that have been disrupted by the trauma.

Reference: Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Dr K. S. Narayan-34th edition; pg:293.

questions.text: Which of the following findings are not seen in autopsy in cases of chronic starvation?
questions.solution:
Typical picture of emaciation and exclusion of any other coexisting cause of death are prerequisite for a definite diagnosis of death due to of starvation. The main autopsy finding is emaciation with loss of body weight and organ weights.

Some findings include -

  • Complete lack of fat in the subcutaneous and deep fat depots.
  • There is severe atrophy of skeletal muscles, lungs, heart, liver, spleen, kidneys, endocrine and reproductive organs (ovaries or testes), except for the brain.
  • In infants, complete atrophy of thymus is pathognomonic of starvation.
  • GIT:
  • Stomach and small bowel are empty along with presence of dry stools in the colon.
  • There is atrophy of the GIT with thin parchment like translucent walls and loss of mucosal folds.
  • Gallbladder bigger in size and distended with bile (food acts as the natural stimulant of bile excretion).
  • The small intestinal wall appears swollen with reddish discolored mucosa and ulcerations of the mucosa of the colon, described as 'pseudo-dysentery'.
  • Edema and peritoneal effusions may occur.
  • Liver: It may show centrilobular necrosis due to protein deficiency.
  • Kidneys: It may show atrophy of nephrons.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:340-41.

questions.text: Which of the following sections of IPC is applicable in the act of causing stillbirth?
questions.solution:
The causing of the death of living child in the mother's womb may amount to culpable homicide, if any part of that child has been brought forth, though the child may not have breathed or completely born (Sec. 299 IPC).

Any person who does an act with intent to prevent the child being born alive or to cause it to die after birth (except done in good faith for the purpose of saving the life of mother) is punished with imprisonment up to 10 years with/without fine (Sec. 315 IPC).

Infanticide is charged under Sec. 302 IPC which is punishable by death or imprisonment for life and fine.

Sec 308 IPC: Attempt to commit culpable homicide.

Sec 314 IPC: Death caused by act done with intent to cause miscarriage. Whoever, with intent to cause the miscarriage of a woman with child, does any act which causes the death of such woman, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:348-49.

questions.text: At the age of 36 weeks IUL, which of the following ossification centres will not be present?
questions.solution:
Ossification centres for lower end of femur, cuboid and capitate appear at 36 weeks of IUL, while ossification centre for upper end of tibia appears at 40 weeks of IUL.


Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:351.

questions.text: What is the normal weight of placenta at full term?
questions.solution:
The features of a normal placenta are:

  • About 15-20 cm in diameter
  • Central thickness of 2.5 cm
  • Weight - 500 g at term

In a case of infanticide, placenta should be weighed to evaluate maturity, and any abnormality should also be observed. Various placental conditions may result in the stillbirth of otherwise completely normal infants.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:349.

questions.text: What is the normal length of umbilical cord at full term?
questions.solution:
The normal cord length is 54-61 cm with short cords measuring <30 cm and long cords measuring >100 cm.

Long cords may cause blood flow obstruction if prolapse, torsion or knotting occurs, and may also wrap around the neck causing asphyxia.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:350.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of Lanugo hair?
questions.solution:
Lanugo hairs are fine, soft, downy and unpigmented hair on the body of the fetus and newborn.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:105.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the Raygat's test?
questions.solution:
Raygat's test.

Procedure: Dissect out the foetal lungs. Put both the lungs (tied at their hilar region) into a trough of water and observe. A small piece of liver serves as control. If the liver floats, the test is of no value.

If the lungssink-unrespired lung.

If they float-remove them from water, cut into small pieces and then squeeze or compress firmly between sponges (to remove the expiratory reserve volume and tidal air) and again put into water.

  • If they sink-unrespired
  • If they float-respired

Fallacies-

  • False positive is seen in accumulation of putrefyinggases or artificial inflation (by intubation and forced air insufflation expanding the lungs with air after delivery).
  • False negative is seen in atelectasis (non-expansion of lungs), obstruction by alveolar duct membrane, edema, feeble respiration, pneumonia and congenital syphilis.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:356.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of a dead born fetus?
questions.solution:
Amussat's sign: Transverse carotid intimal tears may be seen in obese victims, long drops and posteriorly placed knots in case of hanging.

Deuel's halo sign: A halo is seen around the cranial vault due to elevation of pericranial fat by the accumulated fluid in subaponeurotic space. It develops 2-3 days after foetal death. This sign can be seen on USG scan and X-ray, but not a reliable sign.

Robert's sign: Appearance of gas shadow in chambers of heart and great vessels, may appear by 12 h, but difficult to interpret.

Ball sign: Hyperflexion of spine is more common in a dearborn fetus.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:358-59.

questions.text: Eliciting regular rhythmic contractions of uterus by bimanual examination in early pregnancy, is known as
questions.solution:
Palmer's sign: Regular rhythmic contractions of the uterus can be elicited by bimanual examination as early as 4-8th week.

Hegar's sign is positive between 6-10th week.

  • Demonstration: If one hand is placed on the abdomen and two fingers of other hand in the vagina, the firm hard cervix is felt and above it the elastic body of the uterus, while between the two, the isthmus is felt as a soft compressible area.
  • This is the most valuable physical sign of early pregnancy.

Osiander's sign: There is an increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices at about 8th week.

Braxton-Hick's contractions: Intermittent, spasmodic, painless uterine contractions are observed rarely before the 3rd month, but are easily felt after the 4th month. Each contraction lasts for about a minute and relaxation for about 2-3 minutes (min). They are present even when the fetus is dead.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:392.

choices.text: Penetrates his penis into the vagina, mouth, urethra or anus
Inserts any object or any part of his body (not being his penis), into the vagina, mouth, urethra or anus
Manipulates any part of her body so as to cause penetration into the vagina, urethra, anus or any part of her body
Applies his mouth to the vagina, mouth, anus, urethra of a woman

questions.text: Which of the following sentence is false regarding sec. 375 IPC? A man is said to commit 'rape' if he himself or makes a woman to do so with him or any other person the following without will/consent:
questions.solution:
S. 375, I.P.C.:

A man is said to commit 'rape' if he himself or makes a woman to do so with him or any other person the following without will/consent -

  • Penetrates his penis, to any extent, into the vagina, mouth, urethra or anus of a woman; or
  • Inserts, to any extent, any object or a part of the body, not being the penis, into the vagina, the urethra or anus of a woman; or
  • Manipulates any part of the body of a woman so as to cause penetration into the vagina, urethra, anus or any part of body of such; or
  • Applies his mouth to the vagina, anus, urethra of a woman.

Kissing (mouth to mouth) will not amount to the offence of rape.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:403.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of suicidal cut wound?
questions.solution:
Defence wounds: Injuries are seen on the forearm and palm, when the victim may try to ward off an attack by raising hands and arms in defence or by grabbing the weapon.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:217

questions.text: Which of the following weapons can produce beveling of the wound?
questions.solution:
Bevelling cut : If the blade of weapon enters obliquely, the wound will have a bevelled margin on one side with undermining (undercut) on the other side so that subcutaneous tissue is visible, indicating the direction from which the blade entered. If the blade is nearly horizontal, a flap wound is caused. Bevelling can be produced by sharp weapons only.

Presence of a bevelled margin indicates:

  • Sharp cutting heavy or moderately heavy weapon was used.
  • Injury has been inflicted by striking the blade of the weapon. The chances of bevelled margin by drawing or sawing the weapon are almost negligible.
  • Wound is homicidal in nature.
  • Direction of application of the weapon, and the relative position of assailant and the victim.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:219

questions.text: 'Long Scarf Syndrome' is associated with
questions.solution:
Accidental ligature strangulation may occur in the 'long-scarf syndrome' in which a clothing around the victim's neck (scarf or chunni/dupatta') becomes entangled, usually in a stationary or moving mechanical device (e.g., rickshaw or scooter wheel), and the clothing becomes increasingly constricted owing to the continued action of the machine.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:187.

choices.text: Hot, dry and free air movement are favouring factors
It begins in the exposed parts of the body like face, hands and feet
Time required is varies from 3 months to 12 months

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding mummification?
questions.solution:
Mummification is the rapid dehydration/desiccation and shrivelling of the dead body from evaporation of water, with preservation of natural appearances and features of the body. It is a modification of putrefaction (dry decomposition).

It begins in the exposed parts of the body like face, hands and feet and then extends to the entire body including the internal organs. The entire body loses weight, becomes thin, stiff, brittle and odourless.

The process of normal decomposition of the dead body is prevented, as the growth of the microorganisms is retarded.

Factors necessary for the production of mummification:

  • The absence of moisture in the air.
  • Continuous action of dry or warmed air.

The time required for complete mummification of a body varies from three months to a year and is influenced by the size of the body, atmospheric conditions and the place of disposal.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:168.

questions.text: Which of the following information is not derived from examination of hair sample?
questions.solution:
Coma, syncope and asphyxia are modes of death, which cannot be determined from examination of hair.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:107.

questions.text: A dead body in a room was found with an empty container at the side and is having coffee brown colour. The provisional diagnosis can be poisoning by
questions.solution: Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg: 521

questions.text: Drugs which can only be sold on prescription of a Registered Medical Practitioner under the NMC Act belong to which 'Schedule of Drugs and Cosmetics Rules'?
questions.solution:
Both Schedule H and L drugs must not be sold by retail, except on a prescription by a registered medical practitioner.


Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg: 511, https://cdsco.gov.in/opencms/export/sites/CDSCO_WEB/Pdf-documents/acts_rules/2016DrugsandCosmeticsAct1940Rules1945.pdf

questions.text: Autopsy findings of a young male died due to ingestion of unknown corrosive showed leathery stomach. Which of the following compounds is most likely to be ingested in this case?
questions.solution:
The autopsy findings of leathery stomach is due to carbolic acid poisoning.

In suphuric acid, nitric acid and oxalic acid poisoning, the stomach mucosa is black due to formation of acid hematin and shredded.

In nitric acid poisoning, yellowish discoloration of mucous membranes can be seen.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg: 531

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding chronic mercury poisoning?
a.Tremors are not common in workers of glass blowing industry
b.Mercuria lentis is seen
c.Proximal convoluted tubules are not affected
d.Penicillamine can be used for treatment
questions.solution:
Option a - Chronic intoxication from inhalation of mercury vapor produces a triad of tremors, neuropsychiatric disturbances and gingivostomatitis.

Tremors are also called hatter's shakes or glass blower's shakes, as they are common in persons working with mercury in glass-blowing and hat industries.

Option b - Mercuria lentis:

  • It is a peculiar eye change due to exposure to mercury vapor.
  • It is due to brownish deposit of mercury through the cornea on the anterior lens capsule.
  • Slit-lamp examination gives a malt-brown reflex from the anterior lens capsule.
  • It is bilateral and has no effect on visual acuity.

Option c - Proximal convoluted tubules are affected by mercury. Mercury is nephrotoxic.

Option d - N-acetyl penicillamine is the chelator of choice.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg: 541-43

questions.text: Autopsy finding of unknown male shows dark brown postmortem lividity and garlicky odour from stomach. The most probable cause of poisoning is
questions.solution:
The colour of post mortem lividity in acute phosphorus poisoning is dark brown and the odour perceived from the stomach is garlicky.

In cyanide poisoning, the colour of postmortem lividity is bright red/pink and odour is of bitter almond.

There is no specific odour or smell in case of death due to aconite or nitric acid poisoning. In aconite poisoning, the signs are those of asphyxia


Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg: 564-66

questions.text: A 45 year old male was brought to emergency with acute onset of hallucinations, violent behaviour and amnesia. Past history is suggestive of alcohol abuse for 10 years. The patient did not have alcohol for 3 days. He had tremors and high blood pressure with impairment of judgement and insight. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Delirium tremens is an acute organic brain syndrome usually seen within 2-4 days of complete absence from heavy alcohol drinking in chronic alcoholics and the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal.

Signs and symptoms include clouding of consciousness, disorientation, coarse muscular tremors, psychomotor agitation, tendency to commit violent assault, tactile hallucinations. Chronic alcohol abuse can lead to malnutrition resulting in amnesia.

Wernicke's encephalopathy presents with disorientation, confusion, memory disturbances, nystagmus, apathy, ataxia etc.

Korsakoff's psychosis presents with organic amnestic syndrome, characterised by inability to learn new information, impairment of short term memory and compensatory confabulation. Insight is often impaired.

In the delusion of persecution, a person believes that others are making a conspiracy against him to ruin him or kill him.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg: 606-07

questions.text: A farmer was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state with excessive salivation, constricted pupils and fasciculations of muscle. What will be the first choice of drug to be administered?
questions.solution:
The provisional diagnosis based on signs and symptoms is organophosphorus compound poisoning. The specific antidote is atropine.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg: 652-55

choices.text: Formation of phosphine gas when comes in contact with moisture of stomach
Prevents degradation of acetylcholine at neuromuscular junction

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about harmful effects of aluminium phosphide on the human body?
questions.solution:
• Aluminium phosphide forms phosphine gas when it comes in contact with moisture.
  • It is a protoplasmic poison which inhibits protein and enzyme synthesis.
  • Phosphine interrupts states of mitochondrial electron transport by inhibiting cytochrome C oxidase and oxidative phosphorylation resulting in ATP depletion and cell death.
  • It also causes metabolic acidosis.
  • Phosphine and phosphides also have corrosive

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg: 661-62

questions.text: Identify the seeds
questions.solution:
Identification of croton seeds-

  • Seeds are 1.2 x 0.8 cm in dimensions.
  • Oval or oval-oblong and odorless.
  • Dark brown or brownish-gray
  • Resemble castor seeds, but they are not shiny and not mottled.

Nux vomica seeds are circular and semecarpus seeds black, heart shaped with rough projection at the base.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg: 570-71

questions.text: What is the active principle in these seeds?
questions.solution:
The seeds in the image are of Semecarpus anacardium which contains active principle semecarpol.

The fruit of this plant is known as 'marking nut' or 'bhilawa' as its juice is used by washerman/laundries to inscribe identification number on the clothes.

Identification of Seeds -

  • Seeds are black.
  • Cone or heart-shaped with a rough projection at the base.
  • They have a thick, pericarp containing the irritant juice which is brownish, oily and acrid, but turns black on exposure to air.

Strychnine is present in nux vomica and neriodorein is an active principle in nerium odorum.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg: 572

questions.text: Which of the following is the characteristic feature of aconite poisoning?
questions.solution:
Signs and symptoms of aconite poisoning -

  • Leaves handled or rubbed on the skin, produce tingling and numbness; so also the root if held for a long time in the hand.
  • The odour of the plant has a narcotic effect.
  • The pollen causes pain and swelling in the eyes.

The symptoms occur immediately or within a few minutes.

  • There is a burning sensation from the mouth to the stomach and tingling and numbness in the mouth, tongue and pharynx.
  • This is followed by salivation, nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea.
  • Later the mouth is dry and the patient suffers from thirst and is unable to swallow.
  • Tingling and numbness are then felt all over the body.
  • There is headache, giddiness, pallor, profuse sweating, subnormal temperature, the limbs become weak and the patient is unable to walk or stand.
  • Paraesthesias, ataxia and slurred speech occur.
  • There may be twitching of the muscles with darting pains, and cramps and convulsions may occur.
  • The pupils alternately contract and dilate (hippus), but remain dilated in the later stages.
  • The vision becomes dim and there may be diplopia.
  • Hypotension, cardiac arrhythmia with AV block occurs.
  • At first there is tachycardia, but in later stages bradycardia occurs due to AV block.
  • The mind usually remains clear, although there may be hallucinations.
  • There is marked general muscular weakness, oppression in the chest, and death occurs from paralysis of heart or respiratory centres or both.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - KS Narayan Reddy & OP Murty-35th edition; pg: 472

questions.text: Ricin is an active principle of
questions.solution:
• Ricin is the active principle of Ricinus communis (Castor).
  • Crotin is an active principle in Croton tiglium.
  • Poppy seeds are non poisonous and have sedative effects.
  • Hyoscine, hyoscyamine and atropine are active principles in Datura.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg: 569

questions.text:
Which of the following clinical features are seen when these seeds are ingested?
a.Muttering delirium
b.Pin rolling movements
c.Pinpoint pupils
d.Excessive salivation
questions.solution:
Pinpoint pupils and excessive salivation are cholinergic signs.

The seeds shown in the image are of Datura which is a deliriant poison and causes anticholinergic effect. Muttering delirium, pin rolling movements, and carphologia occur in Datura poisoning.

Signs and symptoms of Datura poisoning include -

  • Dryness of the mouth (dry as a bone), bitter taste, burning pain in stomach and vomiting.
  • Dysphagia (difficulty in swallowing).
  • Dysarthria (difficulty in talking) due to inhibition of salivation-mumbling in quality and is often incomprehensible.
  • Dilatation of cutaneous blood vessels (red as a beet). Face is flushed and conjunctiva congested.
  • Diplopia due to dilated pupil (mydriasis) with loss of accommodation for near vision, developing into temporary blindness (blind as a bat) and photophobia. Light reflex is sluggish, and later absent.
  • Dry hot skin(hot as a hare) due to inhibition of sweat and stimulation of heat regulating center. There is dry mucous membrane with dry axillae. Temperature is raised by 1-2°C.
  • Drunken gait: There is giddiness, confusion, restlessness, agitation and unsteady gait, the patient staggering like a drunken individual.
  • Delirium (mad as a hatter): Mutters indistinct words, exhibits typical pill-rolling movements, pulls imaginary thread from fingertips, picks at clothes and tries to run away from his bed. Visual and auditory hallucinations may be present. Patient cannot recognize relatives and friends. Undressing behavior is common. The changes in mental status are characteristic of delirium.
  • Drowsiness.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg: 617-18

questions.text: Amotivational syndrome is seen in which of following poisoning?
questions.solution:
Amotivational syndrome occurs in chronic use of cannabis which is characterized by lethargy and lack of interest in day to day activities at home and school.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - KS Narayan Reddy & OP Murty-35th edition; pg: 457

questions.text: 'Crack lung' occurs in...
questions.solution:
Crack lung may occur 1-48 hours after cocaine smoking.

Clinical features are chest pain, cough, hemoptysis, dyspnea, bronchospasm, pruritus, fever, diffuse alveolar infiltrates without effusions, and pulmonary and systemic eosinophilia.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg: 627

questions.text:
Which of the following alkaloids are derived from the whitish fluid shown in the figure?
i.Morphine
ii.Papaverine
iii.Codeine
iv.Meperidine
questions.solution:
The image shows poppy fruit. The whitish fluid is obtained after incising the poppy fruit. The fluid is dried to get opium. Its derivatives include -


Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg: 590

questions.text: All are the features of Barbiturate poisoning except
questions.solution:
Hypothermia (as low as 310 C) occurs in barbiturate poisoning.

Barbiturate poisoning is characterized by stupor or coma, areflexia and in late cases, severe respiratory depression and cardiovascular insufficiency.


Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg: 613

questions.text: Which of the following is used for stomach wash in case of copper sulphate poisoning?
questions.solution:
Gastric lavage with 1% potassium ferrocyanide causes formation of cupric ferrocyanide which is insoluble, is used in treatment of copper sulphate poisoning.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - KS Narayan Reddy & OP Murty-35th edition; pg: 414

questions.text: A 25 year old male was brought to OPD with a history of drug abuse and synesthesia. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
LSD is a hallucinogenic drug which causes crossing over of senses or altered changes in vision and hearing i.e. seeing smell and hearing colours called synesthesia.

Lysergic Acid Diethylamide (LSD) -

  • Obtained from rye fungus and is rapidly absorbed from the GIT with onset of action in 30-40 minutes.
  • LSD presumably produces its effects by an action on the 5-HT levels in the brain.
  • No physical dependenceor withdrawal syndrome is seen with LSD.
  • A common pattern of LSD use is trip (occasional use followed by a long period of abstinence).

Signs and symptoms of acute intoxication -

  • Somatic or physical: Dizziness, dilated pupils, nausea, flushing, hyperthermia, paresthesia, hyperactive reflexes and tremors.
  • Perceptual: Altered changes in vision and hearing, like floating feeling, illusions, sensation of synesthesia, i.e. 'seeing' smells and 'hearing' colors.
  • Psychic or changes in sensorium: Delusional ideation, body distortion, suspiciousness to the point of toxic psychosis, depersonalization and loss of sense of time.

Treatment includes removing the patient from aggravating situation, anxiolytics and symptomatic treatment

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg: 680

questions.text: Match the following according to the appropriate antidote to the poison and choose the correct option.
questions.solution: Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 667, 642, 592, 690

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding aconite poisoning?
questions.solution:
• The root of aconite is poisonous and sweet in taste.
  • Atropine is used in treatment.
  • It does not cause hallucinations.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 633-34

questions.text: A 24 year old male started feeling that 2 of his enemies are continuously watching him. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In delusion of reference, the person believes that people are referring to him.

Delusion is a false belief, based on incorrect inference about external reality that is firmly held, despite objective and obvious contradictory proof or evidence. The various types include -

  • Delusion of grandeur or exaltation: The patient imagines himself to be very rich, while in reality he may be a pauper.
  • Delusion of poverty: The patient is convinced that he is, or will be, bereft of all material possessions.
  • Delusion of infidelity/jealousy (Othello syndrome): Person holds a delusional belief that his spouse is unfaithful.
  • Delusion of reference: The person believes that he is being referred to by all agencies, media and persons around him in all matters (usually of negative nature) concerning him or others.
  • Delusion of persecution: The patient imagines that he is going to be poisoned by his relatives (wife, sons or parents) or someone is going to rob his property. Persecutory delusions are most common.
  • Delusion of influence/control: The patient complains that his thought processes, feelings and actions are being influenced and controlled by some external power, like radio, hypnotism or telepathy
  • Hypochondriacal delusion: Persistent concern with a fear or belief of having one or more serious disease (like cancer) based on patient's own unrealistic interpretations of physical signs and symptoms.
  • Delusion of self-reproach or self-criticism: The person criticizes himself for some imaginary offence or misdeed committed by him in the past.
  • Nihilistic delusion: The patient does not believe in his existence or the existence of earthly matters or that there is any world. It is commonly seen in depression.
  • Delusion of doubles (doppelganger): Patients believe that another person has been physically transformed into themselves.

In erotomania, the person believes that another person is in deep love with him/her which in fact is not.

In hallucination, there is a false perception of senses.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 443

choices.text: Irresistible desire to set fire to different things
Irresistible desire to pull out hair

questions.text: Dipsomania is
questions.solution:
• Irresistible desire to drink alcohol is called dipsomania.
  • Irresistible desire to set fire to things is called pyromania.
  • Irresistible desire to steal things is called Kleptomania.
  • Irresistible desire to pull out hair is called trichotillomania

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 446

questions.text: A patient died on the operating table of a surgeon during elective surgery. The doctor can be charged under which section of IPC if the death is suspected to be due to negligence?
questions.solution:
IPC 304A deals with criminal negligence. Whoever causes the death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide shall be punished with imprisonment up to 2 years, or with fine or with both.

IPC 304 - Punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder. Whoever commits culpable homicide not amounting to murder shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine, if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing death, or of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, or with fine, or with both, if the act is done with the knowledge that it is likely to cause death, but without any intention to cause death, or to cause such bodily injury as is likely to cause death.

IPC 302 deals with murder.

IPC 304B deals with dowry death.

Ref - The essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Dr KSN Narayan Reddy 34th e, Pg. 39, https://indiankanoon.org/doc/1371604/

choices.text: Conventional laws of courtesy observed between members of medical profession
Study of the effects of violence or unnatural disease
Moral principles which should guide the members of medical profession in their dealings

questions.text: Medical etiquette deals with
questions.solution:
Medical etiquette deals with conventional laws of courtesy observed betweenmembers of the medical profession.

Medical jurisprudence deals with the legal responsibilities of the physician with particular reference to those arising from physician-patient relationship such as medical negligence cases, consent, rights and duties of doctors, serious professional misconduct, etc.

Forensic pathology deals with the study and application of the effects of violence or unnatural disease in its various forms in our on the human body in determining the cause and manner of death in case of violence, suspicious, unexplained, unexpected, sudden and medically unattended deaths.

Medical ethics deals with the moral principles which should guide the members of the medical profession in their dealings with each other, their patients and the State.

Ref - The essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Dr KSN Narayan Reddy 34th e, Pg. 1
